urls.title: Opinion: We have no choice – this has to be the year we reverse the decline of nature
urls.description: The UK can emerge as a global leader in conserving and improving the natural world, but only if we deliver on all the promises we have made

text: From @TonyJuniper @NaturalEngland  @EmmaHowardBoyd @EnvAgency and William Worsley @ForestryEngland > We have no choice – this has to be the year we reverse the decline of nature https://t.co/7dSLKSYS7s

@EmmaHowardBoyd @TonyJuniper @NaturalEngland @williamworsley @ForestryEngland @COP26 @EnvAgency @DefraGovUK Sounds good just hope the work farmers do to contribute to the  objective is recognised & rewarded at market value & not undervalued. 
If it is that important and “the year we ramp up action”, then the incentive must be there. Fail to do  so then it will be an uphill struggle.

@EdenSwimmer @NECumbria @EnvAgency I think for those that manage to spawn, it is the culmination of a successful life cycle. I heard once that multiple spawners usually have more spots on head, but not sure if true. Those that survive are known as kelts when they return to sea.

@TomOrdePowlett @NECumbria @EnvAgency That’s very reassuring Tom. Twitter is great for increasing my knowledge; lots of kind teachers. 

80% is a high mortality - is that of all males or only the older ones that head back up stream for spawning? I think I need a lesson in fish biology.
